Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Machine learning of discourse structure for personalized online tutoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technology in education provides both tremendous opportunities and tremendous challenges.  By delivering instruction online, we may be able to reach a much wider range of students than previously possible.  But, while technology allows instruction to reach more students, it also risks losing the rich interaction and feedback that in-person instruction provides.  To be truly effective, courses need both rich content and personalized interaction and feedback. So, this project seeks to provide a technical foundation for restoring richer interaction to the online learning experience, particularly through natural language content such as discussion boards and peer grading.

The project will develop machine learning techniques for discovering high-level structure in natural language text, including discourse structure (relationships among pieces of text), topic structure, and semantic structure.  To discover this structure, the project investigates the use of spectral learning methods.  These methods, which rely on factoring a matrix or tensor of observed moments, are able to learn latent structures efficiently and without local optima.  Of particular interest and challenge is to develop tractable methods that can learn latent structure from unlabeled or weakly-labeled data.  Many current NLP techniques have difficulty with informal language and do not extract higher level structure; our goal is to develop spectral methods to address these weaknesses. The project will attempt to learn this high-level latent structure in data taken from discussion boards of large online classes.  The idea is that future work could use this understanding to help personalize the way students access this sort of rich natural language content: e.g., by helping to focus searches, find relevant and cohesive content, synthesize answers to student questions, promote productive behaviors in online discussions, and support self and peer grading.  The eventual goal is to provide personalized interfaces to students that facilitate their learning of novel material.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed new techniques to discover high-level structure in documents such as posts in a discussion forum. Examples include high-level topics of documents, or relationships between documents (such as one post being a reply to another). The new techniques are based on novel machine learning algorithms called spectral methods. Compared to previous algorithms, these new methods offer easier optimization, and can ease the burden of collecting relevant data by being flexible about the kinds of data required.

We are interested particularly in applications in education, where technology provides both tremendous opportunities (such as the ability to reach a wider range of students) and tremendous challenges (such as the need to deliver effective feedback to these students). As an initial step in this direction, the project attempted to learn high-level latent structure in data taken from the discussion boards of a large online class. The idea is to use this understanding to help personalize the way students access this sort of rich natural language content: e.g., by helping them focus their searches and synthesize content. Results were promising: we were able to advance state-of-the-art performance on this prediction problem. We hope that better performance on this prediction problems (and related ones) will eventually lead to better-performing ML systems for enhancing participation in online courses.

Beyond the immediate application to education, our new methods hold the potential to improve the way that practitioners build models of text data as well as to a wide range of other time series data. We have worked particularly on robustness and scalability; these improvements will increase applicability of these models and therefore improve the ability of practitioners to extract information from this kind of data.
